>>27950015
One of my favorite stories of all time
I Was a civilian contractor with the Activity - basically Military Intelligence Special Forces. Card-carrying geniuses with 145+ IQs who were also experts in weapons, explosives, etc.
I managed some of their bleeding-edge electronics and had asked the manufacturers to send down some experts to answer questions. Three civilians come in - an obvious engineer in cargo pants and a polo, a woman in an expensive pantsuit and heels with major makeup, and a guy in a $2k suit. All from the manufacturer. So I take them to the unit's common rom to meet the experts
I introduce them to Sgt "Smith", Sgt "Jones" and Sgt "White". They ere watching NASCAR on TV when we came in. Smith had a spit cup for the chewing tobacco in his mouth. Jones was literally playing a banjo, and White had been reading a D&D book
Smith greets them with a thick as fuck Alabama accent. Jones a Georgia accent. White = Carolina. Big smiles
The civilians are obviously bored, ask me
>"Where are the experts from the Activity?"
These ARE the experts. The engineer tentatively asks what the questions were.
Cue a 3 hour deep-dive into wave propagation theory, Huygen's Principle, and mapping out electronic circuits on a white board along with a ton of calculus. When the soldiers learned the well-dressed man and woman were *sales* they blew them off.
The engineer cursed in German so White switched to German to continue speaking with him.
I was grinning at the stunned look on their faces and explained
All three of the sergeants were electronic warfare specialists that were also trained linguists, cryptographers, and intelligence analysts. They were also trained in airborne, amphibious, air assault, and scuba operations, Smith was a demolitions expert, Jones was jungle combat specialist, and White was a desert warfare and survival expert. And they were all looking forward to deer hunting season.

Kurt is one of my favorite historical figures. He's the perfect example of why someone needs to struggle in life. Dude had everything he wanted from a young age. He was literally adored by every single person in his life and he could do no wrong. He constantly tried to tell people how much he hated them, he pushed away everyone. He made utterly ridiculous and extremely controversial statements all the time. He put no effort into his concerts. He didn't even know how to properly play the guitar, he played it backwards. His songwriting was basic, yet his voice was incredibly powerful and the songs he wrote were so different from literally everything else going on. He effortlessly wrote the most iconic songs of the 90s.

And he was miserable. He had no dreams or aspirations in life because he accomplished quite literally everything a man possibly could and he did so effortlessly. Fuck, the dude took a shotgun and blasted his brains out after a long period of ignoring his daughter and shooting up heroin and people like me still talk about how cool of a guy he was.

I hope he makes it in the history books 1000 years from now. If nothing else, an example.

I actually just broke up with my girlfriend of 7 years. The big one was just her views of interpersonal effort... but there were tons of lesser ones too that combined.

Sex was one of them. Before, I'd only had one sexual experience, which was going to a gay club hoping that at least maybe someone would like me. That didn't work out and I never really brought it up with anyone since. To the point at a party where a girl did get interested in me, I panicked enough to climb out a window to GTFO. I ended up using THAT story as my 'I was silly in college' story vs the 'I blew a dude probably way too old for me just so I could maybe feel attractive/liked but also because I was too scared to evac at that point cuz I was basically a fucking kid'.

posts.com:
>>27963322
Cultivate healthy acquired tastes. Maybe there are things that are popular that you just can't seem to find enjoyable. Expose yourself to those things FROM THE PERSPECTIVE THAT SOMETHING IS THERE AND YOU'RE SOMEHOW MISSING IT. It's easy to find fault in things. Force-feed yourself things that the people around you seem to enjoy until something clicks.

That's how I got into metal music. A few of my friends in high school liked it, and I respected that. However, I was always the first to be like "how can you enjoy that, you can't even understand what they're saying?" So I looked up some artists that I knew my friends listened to, and spent one evening listening to their songs. I thought to myself, "ok, this is supposed to be the artists of these genres that sound good, let's try to find the value in it."

That night, after many many songs, I discovered a new energy within myself. That music felt empowering. It's not the greatest music genre there is. Definitely not the kind of thing you play at a party, or a funeral, or a ceremony. But, it does have its place, and I found a place for it by having an open mind.

I feel like it was a lot easier to have that perspective on the music when it wasn't forced on me. By that I mean, I didn't ask anyone what artists I should listen to, nor what songs. That way, there was no pressure to have a concrete answer (either I loved it or hated it), I could be unsure how I felt about it, and not have to have a "report" ready for that person within a day.

The bottom line is that you should try to take interest in the things your peers find interesting, and unless you have a good reason not to, you shouldn't rebel against the conformity of liking things everyone else likes. (A semi-good reason example would be strong political feelings)

It can be a simple as reading a book with someone else, or listening to the same type of music, enjoying cooking or anything. Shared experiences are very big for people.

1. Acknowledge and challenge any irrational, hateful biases you may have. Start by asking yourself why you feel this way - is it due to past experiences, media messages, or other influences? Try to recognize the thoughts and feelings as separate from who you are and try to look at other people with an open mind.

2. Observe any positive aspects of womanhood. Look for the positive role models in your life and those around you. These can be female family members, friends, teachers, mentors, and more. Think about their attributes and the impact they have had on your life, as well as the lives of those around them.

3. Practice self-care and take a break from viewing certain media. Your thoughts will be heavily influenced by what you see and hear in the media, so try to take a break from negative images in order to separate yourself from the messages they portray.

4. Find a support system. Talk to a trusted friend or family member who can provide encouragement and hold you accountable. Support groups, books or online forums can also be helpful in allowing you to discuss your feelings and learn how others are working towards making a positive change.

>>27961858

Considering on average the stock market goes up by 7% and inflation is about 2% a year, you basically want to take enough money such that it beats inflation and doesn't risk fucking up your gains long term.

In other words, your money goes up by 5% a year on average if you include inflation meaning if you want to be safe, you probably want to take about 1% - 2% of any gains you make that year and leave the rest.

So let's say you want a salary of $40,000. You'll need at least 40,000/0.02 = $2,000,000 (0.02 is the percent) in stocks. Your yearly salary would also increase with inflation so two million is essentially the minimum if you want a $40k salary.

It's the same idea with dividends. Regardless, you need a lot of money. You can reduce the necessary salary by moving to a different country with cheaper expenses but in general you'll need a good amount of $$ to live 100% off passive income. You can also take more out every year instead of just 2% but obviously you take a risk (not sure if the risk is low or high to be honest).

btw not a financial adviser so I don't know if my math is right, if anyone can point any mistakes/bad assumptions I made I'd appreciate it

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27960546
If its a fear thing...sounds like she has some issues around birth in general that she might need to work out. A lot of people (especially women who become pregnant) deal with trauma from the way they were born themselves, and it causes a deep fear of pregnancy and birth. Most of the time these fears are so subconscious that the person is not even fully aware of them, yet they dictate all their decisions surrounding pregnancy and birth.

She and you might both benefit from learning more about birth itself. Start with your own births. How were each of you born? Talk to your parents. Get your birth stories, if you have never heard your own birth story before. Your wife might have been born very traumatically, her mother may have had a very difficult pregnancy... all of these things leave lasting impacts on people. My cousin, for ex, was born after 40 hour traumatic labor and they violently pulled her out with forceps. Today she nears 30 years old and is terrified of having children. Most of us, born in western country, were born at hospital and our mothers had traumatic experiences, and that trauma stays with us and informs how we feel regarding pregnancy and birth, whether we feel "safe" or not.

If this sounds like something that you think would be helpful, I highly recommend utilizing the resources at Indie Birth Association
https://indiebirth.org/

Fear is a huge issue for women in pregnancy and birth. But with some insight, knowledge, and a true desire to understand why we feel the fears we feel, birth can be an empowering, transformative experience that resolves the trauma from our early life.

Don't take it personally since there could be many reasons. Maybe you should get to know her more first since for a lot of women, going on a date is something they'd only want to go with someone they've established a clear interest in, and so knowing someone and talking first may be important.

It could be that she isn't interested in going on a date yet but doesn't want to express it because she doesn't know you that well yet and feels the need to be appeasing and not say anything that might be taken the wrong way or taken offense to. She just isn't as comfortable with you yet as she would a friend to be honest.

Just forget about the last conversation and message her with a conversation starter like a question about herself or another open ended question/statement. "How have you been doing lately?" "What are you planning to do this Christmas?" or thereforth

Saying that basically tosses the ball in her court and whether she wants to talk more to you is completely up to her and is clear. If she doesn't respond just sweat it off, it happens to the best of us.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>27962814
>Your salaries are mogged by people with non meme degrees
That because you don't understand how averages work. The only "non-meme" degree where you're going to start out making better money than someone with an 8-week trade certification that cost them $5k to get are medicine, law, and CS. And even the averages for those are heavily skewed by the top 5-10% of earners (read: not your ass).
For instance, most engineers don't actually make great money. You're looking low 100's, topping out. The people making serious money as engineers don't fucking work as engineers, with very little exception. They work in engineering-related patent law, sales, administration, etc. The few who do make their serious money off of being an engineer are either PE's, who foot outrageous responsibility that is not commiserate to their pay a lot of the time, or have patents.
That essentially holds true for all "non-meme" degrees, the only exception again being medicine, law, and CS.
And by the time those adjacent sorts are working their way into making outrageous money, roughly the same number of tradies have worked their way up to owning their own companies, working for themselves, and are also making outrageous money.

The number of construction workers bringing home $100k+ is roughly equal to the number of engineers doing it. The only difference is that there's drastically more construction workers than engineers, so the pay distribution gets hidden in the population size. The handful of incredibly wealthy STEM sorts completely skew the data.

It's definitely the case that you can slog through a CS degree, get a shit job that pays $30k/yr for two years, and then fall assbackwards into six-figures. But those doors are closing fast, so get in while you can.

OP as you can see from the thread, the grass is not that much greener or browner on any side. Why? Wealth inequality. No matter what you choose to do (within reason), there is a much smaller slice of the economic pie for the poor fags (all of us) to fight over. So I nominate this guy as having the best advice in the thread:
>>27962988
>the best degree is whatever you have an advantage in and will motivate you to excel in the field, only you can answer that
This is what I've personally found to be true as well. I've done a lot of stuff in my life:
>Worked for a Congressperson
>Banker
>Cannabis industry
>Door to door sales
>Consulting in a whole range of fields
>Manufacturing (3D printing)
And what I have seen time and time again... is that making yourself money is a function of how smart and how hard you are willing to consistently hustle. The consistency and planning are the key. Usually only the very motivated are able to maintain that kind of output while caring enough to be smart and dedicated to it. So I recommend:
>Think about what you're good at and what you're not good at
>Try and match up your skills to a list of industries and roles
>Research what those roles require / what their daily lives are
And find something you would be satisfied doing. Then think about ways you can make more money at it.

ai bro:
1. Challenge your negative thoughts: Pay attention to the automatic negative beliefs that come up for you - such as “nothing will ever work out” - and challenge them with more supportive or realistic thoughts. Rather than see your life through rose-tinted glasses, strive to develop a balanced outlook with a dose of realism.

2. Look for silver linings: Instead of seeing challenges as set-backs, look for the potential positives. For example, if you're having a hard day at work, focus on skills being learned or forging relationships.

3. Enjoy the little things: Take time to observe and appreciate the small wins and joys of everyday life. Reflect on how much you have in your life, rather than how much you lack.

4. Get some perspective: If you're feeling down, talk to someone who can help you gain insight into the bigger picture and put things into perspective.

5. Make changes: Consider whether any of the situations in your life are causing you to be negative and take action to improve them. This could include anything from unplugging from technology to making changes in your job or lifestyle.

Internet sex addiction treated with naltrexone
J Michael Bostwick 1, Jeffrey A Bucci
Affiliations expand
PMID: 18241634 DOI: 10.4065/83.2.226
Abstract
Malfunctioning of the brain's reward center is increasingly understood to underlie all addictive behavior. Composed of mesolimbic incentive salience circuitry, the reward center governs all behavior in which motivation has a central role, including acquiring food, nurturing young, and having sex. To the detriment of normal functioning, basic survival activities can pale in importance when challenged by the allure of addictive substances or behaviors. Dopamine is the neurotransmitter driving both normal and addictive behavior. Other neurotransmitters modulate the amount of dopamine released in response to a stimulus, with the salience determined by the intensity of the dopamine pulse.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Armed forces might get you the whole package. Many jobs have great opportunities to work all over the world but few has you be really "in the field" (even within the military) so it's best to get a job you want to do and if you want to travel with it there's probably ways. For NGO work Security/military backgrounds can get you in but the competition can be hard unless you get deployed by your nation as a liason officer of specialist. Buisness/economics/political science probably have the hardest competition for international work since every high-profile graduate shoots for the UN and then for any NGO so stay out of that (also it's boring). Logistics is great, really great for going places. Getting a degree in medicine or veterinary medicine (doctor or spec. nurse) basically guarantees you work wherever. Mechanical engineers and tradesmen for stuff like building infrastructure in developing countries but I don't know how much experience is needed.
Professions outside the UN/NGO circuit: Energy engineers for working on oil platforms pay extremely well. Merchant marine pays very well as an officer, but keep in mind most routes for large, global shippers are so optimized you'll rarely leave the vessel longer than a few hours for portside loading/unloading. Overnighting is minimized and usually reserved for one or two harbours per vessel.

Pro/industrial diving can make serious money as well in the energy sector. No idea how you get into that if you don't start as an assault or engineer diver in a national navy though. There's also recreational diving ofc. It's a rough circuit but if you're good and network you can land a cushy instructor job in some tropical paradise but it won't make you money enough to take home.

To get into something quickly wherever you are, high altitude technicians usually get good pay all over the world and certificates are normally a year or two trade school.

>t. ex-merchant sailor, ex-military, ex-NGO security worker

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27961318
I skipped some stuff already mentioned.

In general, working in interesteing, remote places is available for most professions through international organizations. For many you won't make as much money as home though, with a few exceptions. Those being the larger NGO:s or working directly for the UN operating in (semi)warzones. There's less competition (but still competition) in working for smaller organizations in safer countries, but most NGO:s has problems with funding and ideologically-minded people so you there can be a tradeoff between location/experience and bank. But this varies wildly between employer and field though.

So basically, if you want the actual work to be hands-on and on site you need to choose your profession carefully. If you want adventures and travel there are ways for most professions though, and doing something you are good at and enjoy enables you to excel and be competitive.

posts.com:
>>27962762
> amongst the lowest they've ever been since records began.
You're statistically illiterate.
Crude divorce rates (divorces per unit population) have declined significantly from their peaks in the mid-20th century, but they are still well above, say, 19th-century counterparts. And this is mostly because the crude marriage rate has also declined significantly.

Relative divorce rates (i.e. the percent of marriages which end in divorce) are FAR higher than they were in the 19th century, and they've been pretty stagnant, at least in the US, since hitting their peak in the 70s. The issue with calculating relative divorce rates, I assume, is that you have to extrapolate. You don't have the ability to track every single marriage over time, so instead you have to use metrics like "percent of couples still together after X years" at a given point in time. It's important to make sure the methods are consistent between sources.
Regardless of method, though, looking at both the crude marriage and divorce rates over time (search "marriage vs divorce rates over time") makes it plain that the divorce rate remains quite high.

>>27962845
If you actually saw a source that says the divorce rate in the US is 10.5%, it was certainly referring to something much different from the absolute odds of a couple to separate in their lifetimes. Check the method they used to get that figure. They were probably calculating the odds of a couple separating in the first year of marriage or something like that.

How much of the maintenance can you do yourself?

i.e. do you know how to work with fiberglass? Could you rebuild a diesel engine with minimal help? Do you understand DC electrics? Are you prepared to ALWAYS be doing preventative maintenance? Can you tolerate the trade offs, like no onboard laundry/shower/etc?

It's totally feasible but it absolutely takes a certain type of person. The reality is that the main thing you need to worry about is the maintenance. You will never increase the value of the boat, but the work you put in will make it better to live on, better to sail, and prevent it from turning into a death trap. The more of that work you can/are willing to do yourself, the more likely you are to be suitable for the lifestyle.

>>27950770

Actually our story and our thoughts is not so important.

We should try to emphasize having a view that's based on present moment mindfulness and doing good deeds.

So if we find that we have a deep habit of being stuck on our complicated thinking and are self fixated view, then we should try to practice generosity and do more good deeds.

There is a particular view that we can have that is not about someone or something or sometime or someplace.

But rather to experience only here in the present moment and we can deepen and empower that view over time.

But the foundation of being able to do that is that we're involved in morality we're involved in doing good deeds were involved in living a meaningful life.

That helps to stabilize and simplify our mind and to help us be more practical and grounded.

You can totally transform the situation and free yourself but you have to start with doing good deeds meditation letting go.

posts.name: Monk

>>27953724
So in Buddhism we can say that Buddhism itself is a practice.

So I'll answer your question in that regard.

The question of what is the practice regarding understanding the true nature of the self in Buddhism is very much based in dropping our assumption of what the self is.

Maybe there is a self maybe there is not a self, what is the self?

And immediately all those assumptions and preconceived notions we have about self-identity and story and I like to say a real true character and a real true story All those come up and then we begin this practice of dropping those assumptions willing to put them down and then looking into the situation that we find ourselves in right now.

So what exactly is this self?

And for me when I look into this situation I find that yes I'm aware of this " " real true person and a real true story...

But when I drop that assumption there is a kind of present moment looking and present moment experiencing.

This doesn't seem to rely on someone or something or some particular time or some particular place.

But it's actually a kind of curiosity a kind of exploration looking into present moments sensations, present moment mental formations,. Feelings in the body, The seeing capacity the hearing capacity...

So we actually investigate the case The present moment situation and that's how we unravel this fixed notion of this real true person in a real true story.


In that way in Buddhism we have a teaching on no self or non-self which means that what you are is not separate from anything else, and also that everything that makes up so-called you " " is not separate from the Sun the environment from all the other people from everything.

This is a teaching known as interbeing.

And we understand this as being a certain kind of like mark of reality not so much a philosophy or belief.

>what is the middle path bro
You live in an incredibly degenerate period of history. I don't mean that in the /pol/ meme sense of the term "degenerate" but simply that what is considered moderate today would be considered extremely radical by people living during the time of the Buddha.

The middle path is the middle between hedonism and asceticism but you need to seriously consider what those terms mean in the context of Buddhism. The Buddha only gave up on asceticism when he was close to literally starving himself to death. The middle path is not
>oh it's ok to masturbate sometimes we don't want you to do something so extreme as never masturbating
but rather
>It's ok to take care of the basics of food, clothing, and shelter. Living naked under a tree while starving yourself will not help your spiritual progress

Regardless,
>I'm also not a no-fun-allowed wannabe monk either.
I did say that attempting to follow the Pāṭimokkha as much as reasonably possible was for a "serious lay practitioner" and not something to do if you're less serious. But if you're serious about making progress, pretty much everything that is forbidden to monastics is stuff that you wouldn't want to do regardless of whether it was against the rules or not. The relevant stuff is all just dont lie, dont steal, dont kill, dont engage in sexual activity, dont agitate against other people. That's basically all of the first two most serious classes of offenses right there and all of them are actively detrimental to your spiritual progress.

So diligence is something I also have issues with and everyone does in one way or another.

I can't give much great advice on the topic but I can say that one of the things that keeps me from being diligent is setting up an ideal way of myself doing a particular activity

Or becoming a certain ideal version of myself.

If I'm stuck if I'm holding on to that perspective of the ideal activity the perfect activity or the perfect version of myself I'm trying to get to.

Then I keep myself from actually taking that next step and getting involved going in the right direction.

For example I might have a intention that I want to go for a walk or I want to climb a mountain.

And that strong perfect idea of climbing the mountain keeps me from going from a walk which would be good for me which is why I want to do it anyway

So I think the advice here is to forget your perfect offering your perfect activity.

And just take a simple step in the right direction at this moment.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27951026
something you might be doing that is a common mistake in breathing meditation is - intentionally breathing. if you're actually, "manually" breathing in and out intentionally, you're doing it sort of wrong. the breathing process should be natural, diaphragmatic belly breathing.
Thich Nhat Hanh's the Miracle of Mindfulness is a the best book I've found on how to meditate.
I think people expect meditation to be very relaxing and easy immediately, but when you're just starting out it can be difficult and even somewhat painful. In my own practice, I found the lotus position painful for about a week before I adjusted to it. The mental aspect should even out after a little while, the important part is to meditate on a regular schedule rather than only meditating every once in a while - think of it like lifting weights, you really have to keep up your training and do it regularly. Hope this helps

posts.com: I was the same. Feels like it's permanent and just who you are, like a social disease you just have to live with for life. What got me out of it was getting a job in customer service. Cashiering is too easy so I wouldn't recommend that one to learn how to be around people. I was the guy behind the returns and exchange desk. Nothing will give you more insight into how people react and handle anger and stress than that job. And it puts you into difficult situations on the daily so you're always stimulated socially. Customer service, management, head cashiers all good for growing your social skills. I did it for one year and I'm like a whole different person now. Recommend it to anyone that didn't get a lot of prolonged stranger interaction while being raised.

posts.sub: How to get my shit together?
posts.com:
I spent this semester procrastinating. Tomorrow's my midterm and I've been studying all day, and I feel miserable. I don't want to be like this next semester.
How to change my life around and study early and everyday?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27960508
You need to create a routine. Start by doing something everyday at the same time. For example, going for a run at 6am every morning.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27960508

1. Break down your goals into smaller, actionable tasks. Set daily, weekly, and monthly goals for yourself.

2. Create a study plan and stick to it. Set aside specific times each day to study and make sure to stick to it.

3. Get rid of any distractions. Turn off your phone, close social media tabs, and focus on your studies.

4. Reward yourself. After completing a task or studying for a certain amount of time, reward yourself with something you enjoy, like a snack or a break.

5. Take breaks. Allow yourself to take breaks when needed, but be sure to get back to studying quickly.

6. Ask for help. Don’t be afraid to reach out to your professors or classmates if you need help understanding a concept or need feedback on an assignment.

7. Stay organized. Keep track of your assignments and due dates so you don’t fall behind.

8. Get enough sleep. Make sure you get enough rest so you can stay focused and alert during your studies.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27960508
Schedule your day, and then schedule studying and homework into your day.
Also don’t study where you sleep or hangout unless you really have to.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Yes, but I'm actively working toward my "real" life. I want to get back into acting (had a number of paid gigs in college so I know I'm up to doing it), but I've fallen out of practice and need to build up my repertoire again. When I clock out of my day job, I hit the gym to bring my body into better performing form, then I go home and read scripts and browse places for good material to audition with.
It's fine to have those interstitial chapters in life. In many cases it's necessary since a lot of passions are simply not profitable, or in some cases never profitable, and you still need food for yourself. The point is, though, not to dwell on some fantastical endgame and begin to develop and work through actionable plans to get to that real life. If you find yourself waiting for some specific moment to come along to grant you the ability to work, you're already behind schedule since there will ALWAYS be something you could be doing to achieve those goals.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27960709
>truth is, deep down i enjoy being sad, but i also dont. I only see two possible paths in front of me, in one i am a normal man with a family and a good job and whatever else you could want, in the other one Im dead by 30. And right now the second one seems much more preferable, but im also not suicidal. I dont know how to put it into words, it just feels like that's what's going to happen, the natural course of things
You don't like being sad, you've just got some kind of Stockholm syndrome from it. It's predictable and known as opposed to branching out to something new which you fear will make you fail and bring you to a somehow lower state of being.
But as I mention here >>27962222, you need to be looking toward some real goal. By real goal, I mean something tangible and meaningful to you.
If your goal is to simply work, then you would theoretically be just as happy as a McDonald's bitch as you would the owner of your own business. Since that's not the case, you need to narrow that goal to what kind of job you want, where you want to do it, how much money you want to make, and where you might want to go with it if you're only looking at entry shit right now.
If you want a wife and kids, well you can marry some woman from an impoverished country who can push out a couple brats and then you might be stuck with a shitty woman and shittier kids that the wife doesn't raise properly. So like with the job, you need to define the type of woman you want to be with. And it's ok to be superficial to some degree, but don't let that be the focus of your desired woman. Further, you need to determine what kind of man and partner you would want to be in your relationship.
Your goals are targets, and you need them to point the way you spend your time and energy. If your target is vague, then you can become unfocused and demotivated which keeps you in this "not yet real life" attitude.

Dropping out of society is a drastic decision and not one that should be taken lightly. You may find it helpful to speak to a trusted friend or therapist about why you are feeling overwhelmed and unable to cope. Some immediate steps you can take to start the process include: removing yourself from social media and disconnecting from friends and people you know, living in a more isolated area, and avoiding any kind of consumerism. Lastly, it can be helpful to develop coping strategies to maintain your mental health, such as meditation, mindfulness techniques, and engaging in activities that bring you joy.

>Any hints on how to keep this LARP as convincing as possible for as long as possible? Has someone here being in a similar situation before?

Don't long into personal email or messengers or social media from work machines or on work networks.

Don't talk or interact with each other in any way. No lunches. Don't carpool. Pretend like you work at different places.

If somebody is snooping around and figures out you're married from social media because they're randomly looking up co-workers, and THEN goes through the trouble of reporting you to HR, pretty sure you can't be fired. That would be discrimination. As long as it is 100% outside the workplace.

posts.com:
Male 31. I'm considering changing my job, a downgrade, from software developer to working in shops that sell lamps.
We're probably looking at a 20-40% decrease in salary.

My current job is working from home alone alone while wearing sweatpants.
When I say "work" I mean I watch youtube and play video games for 7 hours every day, and sometimes do some coding, but I have to be available at a moments notice. I'm basically locked in my own home made wage-cage where I'm all alone.
It's safe.
It's easy.
It pays well enough.
And I hate it. I've hated it for 4 years now.
Maybe it sounds like a dream job to some, but it makes me feel useless, pathetic, and it's soulcrushing an depressing.

The definition if insanity is doing the same thing over and over again and expect different results. I don't want to be a software developer any more, I'm just jaded beyond recognition.

I know I need a change, and I need to see human beings on a more regular basis even though I'm introverted. But am I a moron for letting go of a seemling "perfect" job on paper? The teenagers dream job?
I have no car, but I own my apartment, and public transportation is really really good here. As long as I can pay my bills that's all I need.

I'm probably looking for validation and approval for a decision like this, but if I'm being retarded and overly romantic please let me know. Maybe I don't know how good I have it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>> And I hate it. I've hated it for 4 years now. Maybe it sounds like a dream job to some, but it makes me feel useless, pathetic, and it's soul crushing an depressing.

I think you're suffering from a case of the grass is greener on the other side. It never actually is. The definition of work is the trading of labour, skills and experience for money. This is an important definition because it reminds us that work isn't the living of life, it's the thing we do to afford to live our life inbetween working hours.

Here's the thing about work, no matter what you do once the novelty wears off you will resent it and grow to dislike it. This happens because work is a thing you have to do even when you don't want to. Work isn't a hobby, it's not something you're going to love every day. Work is work. Enjoyment and passion are for life, not for work.

Right now you're feeling disillusioned because according to you, you mostly sit around watching YouTube and playing video games. That is to say, you don't see in a meaningful way how your efforts contribute to or create anything. Sure you get to see your part of the code working, but you apparently aren't spending the majority of your work hours doing that so it makes your time feel meaningless and valueless. It robs you of purpose.

I don't think it's the job that's the problem, I think it's the fact you exploit the situation to slack off instead of doing your work, putting in 110% and giving your role meaning.

You can go sell lamps and it'll be fun at the outset because it's new, but the novelty will wear off and you'll be right back to square one.
